citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Bird Watching Recreation Demand by 12-Digit HUC in the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract: This EnviroAtlas dataset includes the total number of recreational days per year demanded by people ages 18 and over for bird watching by location in the contiguous United States. These values are based on 2010 population distribution, 2011 U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) Fish, Hunting, and Wildlife-Associated Recreation (FHWAR) survey data, and 2011 U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Forest Service National Visitor Use Monitoring program data, and have been summarized by 12-digit hydrologic unit code (HUC). This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to the EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose: The map, Bird Watching Recreation Demand, illustrates the estimated demand for closely observing, feeding, or photographing birds in the contiguous U.S. Other EnviroAtlas maps show the recreation demand for big game hunting, freshwater fishing, and migratory bird hunting for each 12-digit HUC. Used together or independently, these maps can help identify the estimated demand for recreational activity to inform decisions about land conservation for hunting, fishing or bird watching. The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.
descript.supplinf: This dataset provides information on the potential recreational demand for bird watching by people taking day trips. The data does not provide information about individuals taking over-night trips. Additionally, this data provides information on peoples' distributed demand for bird watching by their expected willingness to travel for that recreational activity. An augmented euclidean distance was used to distribute the days demanded for bird watching. The model to create this data set did not take into account infrastructure, or geographical features (i.e. roads, cities, recreational destinations, restricted areas etc.). Therefore, recreation demand may be higher or lower in certain areas depending on the proximity of recreation destinations and ease of access. This dataset represents the expected recreation demand and does not provide information on actual bird watching activity.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html

procstep.procdesc: Acquired the 2011 FHWAR dataset from USFWS.
Acquired the 2011 National Visitor Use Monitoring Program data from USDA.

Determined regional bird watching participation rate for 1) urban white non-Hispanic, 2) urban non-white and Hispanic, 3) rural white non-Hispanic, and 4) rural non-white and Hispanic using 2011 USFWS FHWAR data.

Regional participation rates were applied to the EnviroAtlas dasymetric population dataset, which reallocates 2010 population from census blocks to 30 meter pixels based on land cover and slope, to determine number of participants by location for each demographic group.

Summed the urban white non-Hispanic with the urban non-white and Hispanic to create a single urban participants layer and summed the rural white non-Hispanic with the rural non-white and Hispanic to create a single rural participants layer using the Raster Calculator.
Survey-derived weighted average days of bird watching per participant per year were determined for each region and demographic group from the 2011 USFWS FHWAR dataset.
Multiplied the average regional participation rates by number of participants to estimate total days per year of bird watching.

Multiplied the total days per year of bird watching data by the proportion of the state-level population that was over age 18 to estimate bird watching for the adult population using the Raster Calculator. The resulting layers were the rural and urban days demanded by origin (DDO) for bird watching by the adult population.
Aggregated the DDO layers to a 480 meter cell to enhance processing efficiency using the Aggregate tool.

Created a 1-dimensional probability density function (PDF) showing probability as a function of distance from the origin point using the 2011 USDA Forest Service National Visitor Use Monitoring (NVUM) data.
Integrated the 1-D PDF over individual map cells in eight directions to create a 2-dimensional probability surface for rural and urban bird watching.
Applied the 2-D kernel density estimator to the DDO map to generate a distributed days demanded map for both rural and urban bird watching using Numpy.
Summed the rural and urban surface to create a total distributed days demanded layer for bird watching using the Raster Calculator.
Summarized the recreation demand for bird watching values by 12-digit HUC using the Zonal Statistics Tool.

Eight of the 12-digit HUCs did not contain any cell center of the recreation demand data and therefore, were ignored in the zonal statistics calculations. An average area weighted calculation was used to approximate the total recreation demand for HUCs 090100080102, 010500021104, 031700090802, 010500040701, 010500021107, 010500040903, 010600030103, 010600030206.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

enttyp.enttypd: The estimated day trip recreation demand for bird watching within each 12-digit HUC in the contiguous United States.

attr.attrdef: Number of day trips per year demanded for bird watching by individuals over the age of 18 distributed within the contiguous U.S.

Twelve Digit Hydrologic Unit Code. This field provides a unique 12-digit code for each subwatershed. Numbers were assigned in an upstream to downstream fashion. Where no downstream/upstream relationship could be determined, numbers were assigned in a clockwise fashion.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary Dataset; Chapter 3 of Section A; Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3.

overview.eaover: This dataset shows distributed days demanded for bird watching. In general terms, the recreation demand for bird watching was determined by creating a kernel density dispersion model using the EnviroAtlas 2011 dasymetric population data. Participation rates per demographic group for bird watching were determined using phone survey data collected by the US Fish and Wildlife Service Fishing, Hunting and Wildlife-Associated Recreation (FHWAR) survey (USFWS, 2011). Willingness to travel by each participant was determined using the National Visitor Use Monitoring (NVUM) program (USDA Forest Services, 2011) which provided information on distance traveled for bird watching day trips. The participation rates were applied to the population data to determine the number of days individuals would participate in bird watching. Those days demanded were then distributed using a probability function of willingness to travel to create the distributed days demanded for bird watching. To represent the results in the EnviroAtlas, the data were summarized by 12-digit HUC.
